author: nvhieu
title: Automated funding catalyst projects
description: Catalystのサポートチームは手作業で提案に資金を提供しているが、この仕組みは多くの時間と労力を必要とする。

f6_assessments.q0: This is a project to write a smart contract to allow automatic disbursement of funds if certain conditions are met to avoid manually releasing funds. This could be a great idea, however there are potentially a lot of issues to be overcome in making sure deliverables are met. How generic can we make this? If a smart contract has to be designed with specific deliverable for every project, this may slow things down even more? It feels to me that a better initial project would not focus on the smart contract but on how can we standardize auditing and measurement of deliverables across projects.
f6_assessments.q1: The team seems to have good experience and have presented a relatively detailed plan. As stated above, I worry that the big issue here is not implementing the smart contracts, but figuring out whether this can be done in a generic way across projects.   I would like to see more in the plan on this as getting it to work on one project won't scale unless it can be made generic.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposers have presented timeline against which delivery can be assed. They have not presented a set of metrics for the measurement of success. Implementation on one project will not change anything for catalyst. It would be good to see metrics on testing and rolling it out across numerous projects so it can be shown to be a scalable solution.

f6_assessments.q0: The team is proposing to develop the automation process for Catalyst funding distribution. Although it is a very important topic, it is not so aligned with the Challenge since it's goal is to create and/or suggest other mechanisms to choose projects and distribute funding to them without going through the usual Catalyst process, which takes 3 months overall, and payment is done monthly. That being said, the concept of this proposal is still valid, but this is probably something that IOG is currently working on already, and the team didn't mentioned anything about talking to IOG about it. A similar thing happened to the Community Advisors rewards mechanism: some CAs wanted to develop a new, improved mechanisms, but they consulted IOG, which mentioned that they were already working on it, so the CAs decided to wait for it to be release instead of working in parallel. In any case, if this proposal is funded, it would be the case to contact IOG and work closely with them, maybe using the budget to pay for the developer to support IOG's development or some other deal, it this is to be the case. The proposers are right when they say that this would highly underber IOG's team and free their time to perform more productive work, which would benefit the whole ecosystem, and what is also essential to scale-up Catalyst. Some KPIs could be added to be able to measure the impact of the proposal, such as number of hours saved by IOG team every Fund, if this proposal is successful.
f6_assessments.q1: The team is known in the Catalyst community, as they are active members in the Eastern Town Hall project, as well as SPOs, Plutus Pioneers and more. They provided sufficient information to verify their identities and background. Nguyen Van Hieu seems to be the only member of the team who is going to work on the proposed smart contracts, and it is mentioned that he participated on the Plutus Pioneers Program. Having participated myself, I'm not sure if the participation there is enough to enable someone to develop the smart contracts mentioned in the proposal, since it's mainly an introductory course. Some past work or code examples and/or repository would really benefit the feasibility of the proposal, as we would know with more assurance that he's able to deliver. The budget is well explained, but some info would be good to be included. For example: is the DevOps going to work full time on this? Also, 2h a week for project management seems good but I see a risk that it might not be enough, specially due to the fact that some involviment with IOG might be needed and recurrent meeting might be necessary. The proposers are aware of some risks that were mentioned in the proposal, but they lacked to mention the risk of working in parellel with IOG and at the end they end up not using their development, and use something developed by IOG itself. The definition of sucess is good, but I believe it was mixed up a bit with a roadmap, which is lacking in the proposal. The time proposed and the quantity of developers seems to be appropriate.
f6_assessments.q2: This proposal mixed up the concepts of Definition of Success and Roadmap. The information provided there is good to know what is going to be done, but the way it is presented is not enough to audit the progress of the development on a monthly basis, which is the way that Catalyst funding works. It the proposal doesn't get funded, the proposers should break it down in monthly steps to make it more auditable. KPIs to measure the impact of the proposal are missing, as mentioned also in the 'Impact' criteria. Not only for the development of the proposal itself, but also to measure its success, for example, as mentioned previously, number of hours saved by IOG team every Fund.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal directly works to address the challenge by creating a smart contract that can automatically distribute funds to proposers after conditions are met. This idea makes sense because it allows for automation and removes potential human error that could be involved with the current catalyst fund distribution process. According to the proposers, the solution will be scalable and transparent, which is exactly what the Cardano community needs out of this challenge.
f6_assessments.q1:
Based on the proposers' experience listed in the proposal, I believe that the proposal will be implemented successfully. The proposers have the combined background knowledge to complete the project, and the proposers mentioned that they will do additional research during the first 3 months of the project to fill in any gaps they might currently have.

I would like the proposers to clarify what cryptocurrency they plan to use because they mentioned a few in the proposal. I think that ada would be the most relevant token, but clarifying that in the proposal would be helpful for voters to better understand the project.

I also appreciate the proposers' honesty in acknowledging that they may come across unforeseen circumstances that could delay the project. One question I have is, in the event that the project is delayed, what will the proposers do to ensure that the community can still place their faith in the proposers to complete the project? Will more funds be needed to complete the project? Will more developers need to be brought into the project? These are some questions for thought.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposers have provided sufficient information to audit the progress and success of the proposal. Their timeline for the project provides key indicators of each checkpoint in the project. Additionally, the proposers mentioned that they will be providing frequent updates and also gave links to their contact information. Thus, I have confidence that the cardano community will be able to check in to see the progress of the project.

f6_assessments.q0:
Ok guys.  Are you hearing about the Van Halen contract clause?  Basically, Van Halen (the rock music band) demanded a bowl full of M&M's as one of their requirements to play in public. As a particular feature, that bowl could not contain any brown M&M's.  If this clause was violated, the band could get paid without performing.  

Absurd as it may seem, this clause was a sampling technique to know if the contract had been read carefully enough to be fully complied with.  That clause was simply a warning.

My favorite alert is the numbers.  Not the numbers buried in literature and academic knowledge (well, I like those too).  Real life numbers.  

So, let's start whit the final: the Budget numbers. 

So, let's start at the end: the Budget figures.  

Project Management salary (according to the proposal):  
2 hours per week, project will run in 9 months= 40 weeks. so total PM time is 80 hours. Hour rate=$60/hours  => PM labor cost is 80*$60=$4800

Project Management salary (according to my calculator):
2 hours per week, project will run in 9 months= 36 weeks. so total PM time is 72 hours. Hour rate=$60/hours  => PM labor cost is 72*$60=$4320

Total budget (according to the proposal): 33,100 USD

Total budget (according to my calculator): $32620 USD

Difference = $480.  Enough electricity to keep a bright brain on for 1 week. 

Additionally, I would say this:  C'mon guys, let's tide a little bit the numbers.  

Although it may look like an automatic, the campaign's gun chamber only has room for a few bullets.  And let me tell you with all honesty: the bullets waiting to be fired from this campaign are as intelligent, compelling and necessary as yours.    Plus, this is the first version of the Rapid Funding Mechanism campaign, so many shots will have to be fired to find a solution.

Overall, the proposal touches on a topic that absolutely needs to be explored.  Smart Contracts are one of the best tricks we have, so why not use it to solve our problems? 

At the same time, the proposal presents an interesting approach to the problem.  

But, Madam voter and Mr. voter, if you find the proposal a bit costly, I don't blame you.  I think so too.
f6_assessments.q1: Please make a link between the information in the "Use of Funds" section and the related activities in the "Definition of Success" section.  This could give the voter a broader perspective of the development of the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: Although the proponents have claimed to publish their progress on Github, there are no KPI's.

f6_assessments.q0: The author proposes a solution to release funds of approved projects based on a Smart Contract instead of manual transfers from the Catalyst team. Although this mechanism will improve the speed of transferring funds, the Challenge is about speeding the funding of new projects by alternative mechanisms to fair and just allocation of our treasury. I think that there was an unfortunate misinterpretation of the challenge goal. From this Fund 6 and on we count with a Challenge Team that will answer Challenge criteria related topics.
f6_assessments.q1: The members of the team have funded projects in F6 regarding smart contracts, are stake pool operators, and Plutus Pioneer Program, showing that they are capable of delivering this type of project. The proposal includes a detailed budget for developing the smart contracts and project management. It also describes the timeline of activities and risk assessment. All that information looks realistic and correct and gives confidence that they can deliver the project.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal includes a timeline of events of 3, 6 and 9 month showing the spectect result on each stage. The budget is tied directly to developers and project manager labor cost in hours with a reasonable hourly rate. However, no KPI and metrics are defined and it gets more clear that there was a confusion on the goal of the Challenge. I recommend to provide KPI and metrics and validate if they are aligned with challenge goals.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal addresses the challenge by clearly stating how it will add value to the cardano ecosystem. The proposal is able to scale to address future problems.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposers have participated in cardano community for sometime. They have the skill to inform and educate new members about catalyst. The present proposal is yet to have an experience but it has a comprehensive with structured plan to implement proposal. A budget has been provided with real timeline to implement project. Provision for risk and challenges have been provided
f6_assessments.q2: The proposers provide a clear plan for implementation with a well defined time horizon. Several metrics have been provided that can be used to measure the progress and success of this proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: I could see Catalyst going in the direction of this project in the future, but I dont think it offers real solutions to the problems of the challenge. They don't really describe where the funding is coming from or how the smart contract conditions will be decided.
f6_assessments.q1: The team does have relevant experience but their proposal is very vague and I dont feel that they have considered important aspects such as funding, governance, and how smart contract conditions could be fair and democratic.
f6_assessments.q2: The allocation of funds is broken down but otherwise the projects goals are not specific enough to meaningfully audit.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposers outline a solution to a problem which is likely to grow as more people become involved with the Catalyst Funding program. f6_assessments.q0: Funding may indeed become more rapid through the functionality of Dapps/smart contracts however this may be a case of one step forward and two steps back as it is not obvious to me how you would make sure such a process is community-driven, transparent and decentralised none of that has been outlined properly here.
f6_assessments.q1: The plan is outlined very weakly for example one of the metrics for success after 3 months is "Find out how to transfer funds (ADA) for projects." I'm not feeling assured by blockchain devs that don't know how to transfer funds between wallets. Outlined for the 6-month target is the following: "Smart-contract Automated funding Coding" this seems like a fundamental feature and should be targeted for 3 months. Another 6 moth target is "Running smart contract on Testnet" once again why is this not targeted for 3 months? Then the target for 9 months is a full launch on mainnet but why ? These 3 months seems arbitrary if the test net launch is a success why wait 3 months !? In general, the 3,6, and 9-month plans seem very rushed and poorly structured. Moreover, the budgeting for this plan seems to be all over the place there is a requested ~$33,000 but $24,000 is for a blockchain engineer for 6 months the full main net launch was scheduled as a 9-month task whos going to pay the blockchain engineer for the other 3 months ! Then we $4,300 for Dapp architecture why can the blockchain engineer architect the dapp this isn't such a big project ? Then there's $4800 for a project manager for just 2 hours a week I don't think this is a good spend of resources as 2 hours is not enough for a project manager to make a considerable difference to the project. The biggest problem is where is everything else in the budget!? No marketing, no idea of how the initial funding will work ! Who is going to fund these projects where is that cash going to come from !?
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer of this project are public they have outlined their Facebook, LinkedIn, websites, emails, Twitter, telegrams this is some more appreciated transparency. However, there is no sufficient outline for how the project funds can and will be audited.
